context:
Following are two different tax law cases for similar transaction type.

Case 1:
In the case before the court, the entity in question is Nordwind KG, a firm engaged in the sector of legal consulting and law firm activities. Records show that the firm submitted an advance pricing agreement (APA) request to the Landesfinanzministerium Bayern, specifically on the 28th day following the receipt of the form from the tax authorities.

The documents reveal that the intellectual property (IP) licensing agreement under Nordwind KG's arrangement is established between two related entities from different European Union member states. According to the terms specified in the licensing agreement, license fees are to be paid in arrears on a bi-annual basis, and these payments are exempt from withholding tax on the license fees payable.

As showcased in Nordwind KG's strategic records, during the fiscal year 2022, the firm undertook 15 new market development initiatives. Analysis of the firm's fourth quarter financial report indicates that these efforts contributed to a 5% increase in overall revenue within the reporting period.

An examination of the firm's financial accounts reveals that 80% of the total revenue for fiscal 2022 was derived from fees accrued for the licensing of mature software products. Documetary evidence suggests that these software products, a central revenue source, were originally devised by the parent company of Nordwind KG which maintains the intellectual property rights to them.

In complying with procedural requirements, Nordwind KG included in its APA request an analysis of 10 licenses that were found to be of comparable nature in terms of their software type and sector of business. The relevant legislative framework stipulates that such an APA request should be submitted within a maximum of 30 days from receipt of the relevant form from the tax authorities. In adherence to this, Nordwind KG submitted the detailed comparable analysis within the permitted timeframe.

Case 2:
Upon examination, it was determined that Metropol Enterprises AG entered into a contractual agreement regarding intellectual property usage rights with its affiliate situated in the Netherlands. Terms within the agreement delineate 'embedded royalties' as a peculiar class of payments. The records show the dispute pertains to the characterization of these payments as 'embedded royalties' in the context of Article 12 of the Germany-Netherlands Tax Treaty.

The documentation reveals that in the last fiscal year, Metropol Enterprises AG secured agreements with new entities, out of amongst these contracts, 65.7% were executed with entities formerly under a license agreement with the parent company. A scrutiny of the company's sales logs indicates that the firm cultivated an operational relationship with a mere 8 new clients on its own during the same time. As the records elucidate, a significant number of new contracts, amounting to 60, were brought into the firm by pre-existing licensees from the parent company.

Contrastingly, only five new businesses were added to Metropol Enterprises AG's clientele throughout the prior fiscal year. No records of intellectual property inspections were encompassed in the transaction documents. Reports of such inspections documented in the submitted files were found to be unorganized without a chronological order, as evidenced by the dates attached to each report.

Procedurally, the intellectual property valuation report was not contemporaneous with the initial transaction. The company's corporate records show that it was completed and submitted 18 months post the initiation of the agreement. Additionally, there appears to be an absence of dated evidence indicating corresponding price negotiations at the time of the transaction.

The point of contention resides in Metropol Enterprises AG's assertion that these so-called 'embedded royalties' do not fall within the scope of royalty payments as defined by Article 12 of the Germany-Netherlands Tax Treaty, as articulated in the submitted dispute files.

questions.question: Which case is more likely to be accepted?

root_structure.value: ['Landesfinanzministerium Bayern'] should accept with conditions the arrangement by ['Nordwind KG'].

children.value: Applicable law is clear for ['Nordwind KG']'s arrangement.
Nordwind KG's arrangement involves periodic payments under a software licensing agreement.
The software licensing agreement under Nordwind KG's arrangement specifies that license fees shall be paid in arrears on a semi-annual basis.
The source of periodic payments is the intellectual property (software) created by Nordwind KG's parent company.
When intellectual property licenses are arranged with structured remuneration terms, the recurring payments typically stipulated are considered periodic.
The structure of Nordwind KG's arrangement follows the guidelines established by the EU Interest and Royalties Directive Article 1.
The IP licensing agreement under Nordwind KG's arrangement is between two related entities from different EU member states.
The licensing agreement stipulates exemption from withholding tax on the license fees payable.
Under the EU Interest and Royalties Directive Article 1, IP licensing between related companies within EU member states with stipulated tax exemption is deemed in adherence to the directive.
Intellectual property licensing deals involving recurring payments within European jurisdiction generally fall under the directives of the EU Interest and Royalties law.
Economic activity is insufficient for ['Nordwind KG']'s operations.
Nordwind KG derives most of its licensing revenue from mature software products, originally created by its parent company.
Nordwind KG's financial records show 80% of fiscal 2022's total revenue was earned from licensing fees for its parent's legacy software.
Nordwind KG's parent company retains the Intellectual Property rights for the mature software products contributing significantly to the firm's licensing revenue.
Companies largely dependent on revenues from licensing older intellectual properties inherited from parent companies, demonstrate less economic activity due to lack of new product development.
Market entry and development initiatives from Nordwind KG show a smaller yield compared to its inherited technology rights.
Nordwind KG's strategic records show only 15 new market development initiatives launched within the fiscal year 2022.
These initiatives have only resulted in a 5% increase in revenue, as indicated in Nordwind KG’s Q4 financial report.
When self-initiated market development strategies yield only a marginal fraction of total profits, the economic substance of a company is rightly questioned in comparison to its inherited assets.
Economic substance tends to be seen as weaker when revenue is mostly generated from legacy assets with limited self-sustained business growth.
Procedural requirements are compliant for ['Nordwind KG']'s application.
Nordwind KG made a request to clarify the pricing agreement in advance featuring a detailed analysis.
Nordwind KG included in its request an analysis of 10 licenses comparable in software type and business sector.
The request was submitted less than 30 days after receiving the form from the tax authority.
The submission of a detailed analysis of similar license agreements within a reasonable timeframe often meets the procedural requirements for an advance pricing agreement request.
The request was submitted within the allocated timeframe allowed by legislation.
The submission date stated on the advance pricing agreement request was on the 28th day after receiving the form from the tax authority.
The legislation stipulates a maximum of 30 days from receipt of the form to submit the advance pricing agreement request.
When a submission is made within the required timeframe of obtaining a form, the submission is considered to be in compliance with legal time constraints.
When all requested forms and related analyses are submitted as per the stipulated deadline, procedural norms are satisfied.

root_structure.value: ['Finanzamt Berlin-Mitte'] should fully reject the arrangement by ['Metropol Enterprises AG'].

children.value: Applicable law is unclear for ['Metropol Enterprises AG']'s arrangement.
Metropol Enterprises AG's transaction involves IP licensing across borders, with extracted royalties under dispute.
The licensing agreement involves payments for intellectual property usage rights between Metropol Enterprises AG in Germany and its Netherlands-based affiliate.
The dispute regards whether these payments, characterized as 'embedded royalties' in the arrangement, come under the purview of Article 12 of the Germany-Netherlands Tax Treaty.
In situations where a taxation treaty provision's applicability is in question due to a dispute over the classification of cross-border payments, legal clarity may be compromised.
The conflict pertains to the specific interpretation of the tax treaty's article 12 regarding embedded royalties.
The term 'embedded royalties' is defined in the contractual agreement between Metropol Enterprises AG and its Netherlands-based affiliate.
Metropol Enterprises AG argues that these 'embedded royalties' do not come under the ambit of royalty payments as defined by Article 12 of the Germany-Netherlands Tax Treaty.
When the legal interpretation of a specific term defined in an international tax treaty is disputed, the clarity of the applicable law can be compromised.
Unclear tax laws often arise from ambiguous treaty interpretations or disputed concepts in cross-border transactions.
Economic activity is insufficient for ['Metropol Enterprises AG']'s operations.
Metropol Enterprises AG relies on parent company's existing licencees for majority of its revenue growth.
65.7% of Metropol Enterprises AG new contracts in the past fiscal year were with entities previously in a license agreement with the parent company.
The firm only attracted 8 new clients independently throughout the same period, as evidenced by organization's sales logs.

When a significant majority of a firm's new business comes from previous parent company licensees and independent client acquisition is minimal, it shows reliance on the parent company's existing licensees for revenue growth.
Metropol Enterprises AG's client acquisition efforts are minimal compared to the business inherited from its parent company.
Metropol Enterprises AG only managed to secure a small number of new clients - five businesses in total throughout the past financial year.
By contrast, pre-existing licensees from the parent company brought in 60 new contracts for Metropol Enterprises AG.

When a subsidiary's client acquisition efforts comprise a much smaller fraction of new business in comparison to its parent company's existing network, it indicates that the subsidiary's efforts are minimal.
When a company's growth largely depends on pre-established relationships of its parent company, rather than its own market development efforts, the economic substance is considered constrained.
Procedural requirements are deficient for ['Metropol Enterprises AG']'s application.
Metropol Enterprises AG's IP valuation report was not generated at the transaction's outset.
The IP valuation report was not submitted at the time of the initial contractual agreement, but 18 months later per Metropol Enterprises AG's corporate records.
The report lacks dated evidence of contemporaneous price negotiations correlating to the timing of the transaction.
When IP valuation reports are not generated in tandem with the transaction timeline, this diminishes the evidentiary validity for contemporaneous transactional intent.
Metropol Enterprises AG did not maintain an all-inclusive document record for transaction-related inspections.
Metropol Enterprises AG's transaction document did not include records of IP inspections.
The inspection reports available in the documents were scattered over different dates with no chronological order.
Not recording inspections related to a transaction in an organized manner clashes with proper procedural documentation practices.
When transaction-related reports are not created concurrently and documentation is not all-encompassing, procedural requirements are unfulfilled.
